conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to determine the charge that passes through R1 when the switch S is opened.
Determine the initial charges on the capacitors when the switch S is closed.
The total resistance in the circuit is R_total = R1 + R2 = 4.0 Ω + 6.0 Ω = 10.0 Ω.
The voltage across R1 is V_R1 = (R1/R_total) * E = (4.0 Ω/10.0 Ω) * 10 V = 4 V.
The voltage across R2 is V_R2 = (R2/R_total) * E = (6.0 Ω/10.0 Ω) * 10 V = 6 V.
The charge on C1 is Q_C1 = C1 * V_R1 = 30 μF * 4 V = 120 μC.
The charge on C2 is Q_C2 = C2 * V_R2 = 30 μF * 6 V = 180 μC.
Determine the charges on the capacitors when the switch S is opened.
The total charge on the capacitors is Q_total = Q_C1 + Q_C2 = 120 μC + 180 μC = 300 μC.
The equivalent capacitance of the two capacitors in series is C_eq = (C1 * C2)/(C1 + C2) = (30 μF * 30 μF)/(30 μF + 30 μF) = 15 μF.
The voltage across the equivalent capacitance is V_eq = Q_total/C_eq = 300 μC/15 μF = 20 V.
The charge on C1 after the switch is opened is Q_C1' = C1 * V_eq = 30 μF * 20 V = 600 μC.
Find the difference in charge on C1 before and after the switch is opened.
The charge that passes through R1 is the difference in the charge on C1: Q_pass = Q_C1' - Q_C1 = 600 μC - 120 μC = 480 μC.
